body: Tour, With Music, Trinity Episcopal Church, Seventh and Washington Streets, Hoboken, N.J.; (201) 653-1999. Seven Victorian townhouses and a landmark church will be included on the annual Hoboken House Tour on Sunday from 1 to 6 P.M. title: Events: Homes of Brooklyn and Hoboken

body: LEAD: Only a short distance from the polished glass towers of the United Nations, where 71 world leaders have converged this weekend for the first global summit on children, the very symptoms and conditions the leaders would eliminate still fester, in places like central Harlem, where the infant mortality rate is the same as Malaysia's. Only a
title: WORLD SUMMIT FOR CHILDREN; In Harlem, Children Reflect the Ravages U.N. Seeks to Ease

body: LEAD: It is 2 P.M. on the Cross-Bronx Expressway, and for thousands of cars inching toward the George Washington Bridge, the air is heavy with exhaust. Half a mile ahead, where the highway and the Henry Hudson Parkway feed into the bridge's seven westbound lanes, traffic is stopped. It is 2 P.M. on the Cross-Bronx Expressway, and for thousands of
title: Commuters Agonize as Road Repairs Spread

body: LEAD: New York's new striped bass regulations went into effect yesterday and sport fishermen are now allowed to take one bass a day 36 or more inches long, and a limited commercial harvest of smaller fish will be permitted. The state's Department of Environmental Conservation had originally proposed a 28-inch minimum length limit for recreational
title: Outdoors; Shorter Striped Bass Restrictions

body: LEAD: The fates, mainly in the form of a light rain and tractor-trailers, conspired against drivers in New York City yesterday. title: A Light Rain and Heavy Trucks Entangle New York City Traffic

body: LEAD: In the final hours before leaving for its summer recess, the Senate gave final approval late Saturday to legislation to provide more than $4 billion over the next five years to help cities deal with AIDS and to provide money to upgrade airports, mass transit systems and Amtrak. In the final hours before leaving for its summer recess, the
title: Senate Approves Measures on Transit and AIDS

body: LEAD: It has been decades since most city residents had milk delivered to their homes and longer still since milkmen used horse-drawn wagons. title: Postings: Park Slope Project; Co-oping a Milk Wagon Barn

body: LEAD: The Revolutionary battlegrounds of New York, submerged beneath the city's shell of iron and concrete and contemporary belligerency, sometimes seem as irretrievably lost as an Atlantis. At this time of year, the story of independence that must be told each Fourth of July has a chapter that describes the fate of the city and its surroundings
title: When America Was New

body: LEAD: Two Manhattan-bound lanes on the Queensboro Bridge were closed for rebuilding yesterday, causing a major traffic jam. Traffic officials said the construction, like the work on the bridge last summer, would continue to delay drivers every day, and they recommended that drivers switch to mass transit. title: Time for Bridge Traffic Jams

body: LEAD: ALTHOUGH vacant for a quarter of a century, the New York State Barge Canal Grain Elevator still dominates the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, its vast spread of concrete bins a ghostly silhouette. title: Streetscapes: The Columbia Street Grain Elevator; Recycling Red Hook's 1922 Magnificent Mistake

body: LEAD: In 1986, Staten Island got a break when the eastbound toll of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was removed to speed traffic to Brooklyn and reduce air pollution. To the delight of Staten Islanders, the change has worked as intended. In 1986, Staten Island got a break when the eastbound toll of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was removed to speed
title: S.I.'s Relief Called Brooklyn's Headache

body: LEAD: For years, dance in Brooklyn was mostly a matter of the large companies presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In 1985, smaller-scale and more informal modern dance began to become established in less august theater spaces in the borough, principally at BACA Downtown, and Spoke the Hub Dancing's Gowanus Arts Exchange. title: Two Not-So-August Outposts for Modern Dance

body: LEAD: Brooklyn has long been a major site of that essential art-world ritual, the studio visit, the pilgrimage that dealers, critics and collectors make to encounter artworks and artists in their natural habitats. The borough is home to many artists, and countless others commute from Manhattan for bigger, lighter, less-expensive working space.
title: Review/Art; A Sprinkling of Exhibitions Near Factories and the Water

body: LEAD: A round house designed with a crafts collection in mind and a pair of two-story lofts that now resemble ''a building within a building'' were among the entries cited as the best and most creative work of New York architects in a competition sponsored by the American Institute of Architects. title: Architects Recognize 17 Projects

body: LEAD: Even the most conscientious cartographers could not find Park Slope South on any map of Brooklyn. But it exists in the minds of real estate brokers, according to William J. Kane, a Brooklyn developer, and who knows, it may catch on as the new more-marketable name for the area west of Greenwood Cemetery and east of Gowanus Bay that up to now
title: POSTINGS: Park Slope South?; 20-Unit Condo for Brooklyn
